snippet.textDisplay:
My favourite video game ever

Currently replaying it for‚Ä¶god I don‚Äôt even know at this point, I can only assume it‚Äôs my 6th or 7th playthrough

I love it, I love the simplicity of the bosses, not as hectic or crazy as the other games, the level design is mechanically and aesthetically fantastic, the combat‚Äôs slower pace makes for an enjoyable time, the story is one of my favourites in fiction, the characters are as loveable as they come (if I could ever fight alongside Solaire, Siegmyer, Laurentius and Logan, I think I‚Äôd finally be able to die happy), the atmosphere is the least depressing in the series which says a lot when comparing to Elden Ring, the DLC bosses are some of my favourites in the entire series and gaming in general, just overall an experience I cherish with all my heart

10/10, I keep harassing my coworker to buy it
snippet.textOriginal:
My favourite video game ever

Currently replaying it for‚Ä¶god I don‚Äôt even know at this point, I can only assume it‚Äôs my 6th or 7th playthrough

I love it, I love the simplicity of the bosses, not as hectic or crazy as the other games, the level design is mechanically and aesthetically fantastic, the combat‚Äôs slower pace makes for an enjoyable time, the story is one of my favourites in fiction, the characters are as loveable as they come (if I could ever fight alongside Solaire, Siegmyer, Laurentius and Logan, I think I‚Äôd finally be able to die happy), the atmosphere is the least depressing in the series which says a lot when comparing to Elden Ring, the DLC bosses are some of my favourites in the entire series and gaming in general, just overall an experience I cherish with all my heart

10/10, I keep harassing my coworker to buy it

snippet.textDisplay: The fact that you didn't use a year in your title is an instalike for me (is it worth in <insert year here).  I find that so stupid!!!  So, thank you for that.    Anyway...  I was so afraid of starting these games.  Everyone made them out to be this impossible thing that it seemed to not be worth it.  I put it off for years.  I started playing this game 2 weeks ago and I can't put it down.  I played ds3 first, because I kept seeing people say it was the most beginner friendly.  While I do agree that it is friendlier, I have to say, ds1 is much better.  I love how interconnected the whole thing is.  It's not easy, that's very much true, but it's not impossible either.  I think it's worth it, regardless of when you play it.
snippet.textOriginal: The fact that you didn't use a year in your title is an instalike for me (is it worth in <insert year here).  I find that so stupid!!!  So, thank you for that.    Anyway... I started playing this game 2 weeks ago and I can't put it down.  I played ds3 first, because I kept seeing people say it was the most beginner friendly.  While I do agree that it is friendlier, I have to say, ds1 is much better.  I love how interconnected the whole thing is.  It's not easy, that's very much true, but it's not impossible either.  I think it's worth it, regardless of when you play it.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm playing through the Dark Souls Remastered for the very first time and started my game last week. I just completed the Zen Fortress (which turns out to be not so "zen" lol) and I too am surprised by how charming this game is, despite all of its grievances for its age. I killed an NPC that I mistook for an enemy which apparently locked me out of a quest and there's certain ways to almost completely ruin your entire playthrough if you aren't careful, but beyond that I am playing through it without a guide (except for hints on where to find key items or rings/weapons/shields early on) as much as I can and to be honest, playing it this way feel so much more immersive than it would with using a guide. I did that with Demon's Souls when I played that game and felt it was a bit more justified due to how that game's world design is structured compared to DS1, but I gotta say that one of my favorite aspects of Dark Souls 1 is definitely the exploration and just feeling like I'm on this incredibly awesome journey while traversing through these precariously hellish landscapes, and to anyone playing it for the first time, I strongly suggest to try avoid using a guide (unless you get really stuck and don't know where to go next, which will likely happen a lot) as much as possible! Even the backtracking doesn't feel like as much of a chore as much as I thought it would because of how enthralling the environments and atmosphere feels in this game. It's truly one of a kind!
snippet.textOriginal: I'm playing through the Dark Souls Remastered for the very first time and started my game last week. I just completed the Zen Fortress (which turns out to be not so "zen" lol) and I too am surprised by how charming this game is, despite all of its grievances for its age. I killed an NPC that I mistook for an enemy which apparently locked me out of a quest and there's certain ways to almost completely ruin your entire playthrough if you aren't careful, but beyond that I am playing through it without a guide (except for hints on where to find key items or rings/weapons/shields early on) as much as I can and to be honest, playing it this way feel so much more immersive than it would with using a guide. I did that with Demon's Souls when I played that game and felt it was a bit more justified due to how that game's world design is structured compared to DS1, but I gotta say that one of my favorite aspects of Dark Souls 1 is definitely the exploration and just feeling like I'm on this incredibly awesome journey while traversing through these precariously hellish landscapes, and to anyone playing it for the first time, I strongly suggest to try avoid using a guide (unless you get really stuck and don't know where to go next, which will likely happen a lot) as much as possible! Even the backtracking doesn't feel like as much of a chore as much as I thought it would because of how enthralling the environments and atmosphere feels in this game. It's truly one of a kind!

snippet.textDisplay: Currently playing it after Elden Ring, and man my opinion could not be further from yours. Mechanically, it feels horrible. The controls, wtaf? So much of the bosses and level design seem to be based around frustrating you, whether it's huge runbacks, or ganks, backtracking, etc. Nothing is explained to you so I guess you've gotta muddle through and hard study the explanations of the stats menus or just go online? Currently in Blight Town and only stubbornness is keeping me going.
snippet.textOriginal: Currently playing it after Elden Ring, and man my opinion could not be further from yours. Mechanically, it feels horrible. The controls, wtaf? So much of the bosses and level design seem to be based around frustrating you, whether it's huge runbacks, or ganks, backtracking, etc. Nothing is explained to you so I guess you've gotta muddle through and hard study the explanations of the stats menus or just go online? snippet.textDisplay: I've finally started playing Dark Souls Remastered after watching all the speedruns of Soulsborne games for years. I'm glad to start here- the online play is still going on despite Elden Ring's release, I love the exploration and intimate knowledge of the game space, and I can practice my combat skills before the more demanding games, like Bloodborne or Elden Ring.
snippet.textOriginal: I've finally started playing Dark Souls Remastered after watching all the speedruns of Soulsborne games for years. I'm glad to start here- the online play is still going on despite Elden Ring's release, I love the exploration and intimate knowledge of the game space, and I can practice my combat skills before the more demanding games, like Bloodborne or Elden Ring.

snippet.textDisplay: U don‚Äôt have to rest in the birds nest if you don‚Äôt want to, it‚Äôs completely optional. All it does is it takes you back to the beginning asylum and u can fight another version of asylum demon, also u can get a doll there that lets u go to the painted world. Also Pickle Pee is at the asylum so if u want to give it something in return for another item, u can do that.

snippet.textDisplay: There is fast travel with the lord vessel. But I think I like how you can't fast travel in the first half of the game because it gives the game more of a sense of exploration, making you appreciate the world even more. One problem I had with Dark Souls III was that I didn't really find each place to be as memorable due to the fast travelling. Fast travelling right away just takes away from the exploration experience.
snippet.textOriginal: There is fast travel with the lord vessel. But I think I like how you can't fast travel in the first half of the game because it gives the game more of a sense of exploration, making you appreciate the world even more. One problem I had with Dark Souls III was that I didn't really find each place to be as memorable due to the fast travelling. Fast travelling right away just takes away from the exploration experience.

snippet.textDisplay:
Somewhat unrelated but I played demon soul on PS5 and I hated it

It was fun until I realize you gotta walk through the entire map over again if you die
I don‚Äôt like grinding over the same small linear corridors area and it‚Äôs a shame cause I love the combats of souls games.
That brings me to elden ring,elden ring not only is completely open world but also makes you respawn near the boss instead of far away,my point is it seems elden ring was made with impatient players  who enjoys open world games in mind.

I also think grinding in an open world is much better since you can grind enemies by exploring new areas instead of grinding for hours in the same small linear level.
Dark souls probably has what I hate from souls games but I enjoy watching it on YouTube,I recognize it‚Äôs a great game for player willing to push through it‚Ä¶I just really hoping elden ring respect my time most of all cause I don‚Äôt have time to walk 10 kilometres just to try a boss again.
If it wasn‚Äôt for that I would absolutely love this franchise,If only!üò´

If it wasn‚Äôt for that I would absolutely love this franchise,If only!üò´

snippet.textDisplay: 6:33 you aren't, that wasn't really intended by the developers. The normal way to get it is to cut off the dragon's tail while fighting it on the bridge, but that's kinda hard so people found a way to cheese it.
snippet.textOriginal: 6:33 you aren't, that wasn't really intended by the developers. The normal way to get it is to cut off the dragon's tail while fighting it on the bridge, but that's kinda hard so people found a way to cheese it.

snippet.textDisplay:
great video as always. i beat ds1 and ds2 in 2014 and never looked back bc i think the combat system is fucking awful and completely unusable. what i do like about ds1 is the atmosphere of the in media res, the mid-apocalypse for lack of a better term. i dont like the shortcuts the devs took to compromise what little of that they had, but it still works for me years later.

as for ds1r specifically, you should know its basically just an online patch. the original port was just for switch, so all other version are technically for switch limitations even on ps4 or xbone. its really unfortunate bc as i slogged thru ds1 i could see where things were unfinished (like the demon ruins, lost izalith, the final area around the kiln and the crystal caves) and i hoped with the success of the series they might actually complete the work on the game and improve the combat. not only have they done the opposite of this with newer games, but theyve added more and more broken systems like in sekiro and elden ring. im looking forward to elden ring, but i have low expectations.

im happy you persevered and found something worthwhile for your effort, but i will never forget how utterly disrespected i felt playing ds1 and ds2 and how i beat them spitefully to prove to my former friends that i could do it. i really hope the next generation of soulslikes are actually fun to play, since scarlet nexus and code vein are heavily influenced by souls and nexus' gameplay is leagues ahead.
snippet.textOriginal:
great video as always. i beat ds1 and ds2 in 2014 and never looked back bc i think the combat system is fucking awful and completely unusable. what i do like about ds1 is the atmosphere of the in media res, the mid-apocalypse for lack of a better term. i dont like the shortcuts the devs took to compromise what little of that they had, but it still works for me years later.

as for ds1r specifically, you should know its basically just an online patch. the original port was just for switch, so all other version are technically for switch limitations even on ps4 or xbone. its really unfortunate bc as i slogged thru ds1 i could see where things were unfinished (like the demon ruins, lost izalith, the final area around the kiln and the crystal caves) and i hoped with the success of the series they might actually complete the work on the game and improve the combat. not only have they done the opposite of this with newer games, but theyve added more and more broken systems like in sekiro and elden ring. im looking forward to elden ring, but i have low expectations.

im happy you persevered and found something worthwhile for your effort, but i will never forget how utterly disrespected i felt playing ds1 and ds2 and how i beat them spitefully to prove to my former friends that i could do it. i really hope the next generation of soulslikes are actually fun to play, since scarlet nexus and code vein are heavily influenced by souls and nexus' gameplay is leagues ahead.

snippet.textDisplay: The only souls games ive finished would be Sekiro and Demon's Souls (original), hearing you talking about DS Remastered makes me want to go back and give it another try though. I think if i allow myself to look up stuff when i feel lost, and just open myself to taking my time exploring in general, then i'll have a much better time of it. Also im curious, Apox, of the souls games you've played is there one game in particular whose NPCs you enjoyed the most? I know for DS a lot of people enjoy Solaire but he's usually the only one i hear things about.
snippet.textOriginal: The only souls games ive finished would be Sekiro and Demon's Souls (original), hearing you talking about DS Remastered makes me want to go back and give it another try though. I think if i allow myself to look up stuff when i feel lost, and just open myself to taking my time exploring in general, then i'll have a much better time of it.
